quizDescription: Test your knowledge about XSS attacks and protection methods

questions.question: What does XSS stand for?
questions.explanation: XSS stands for Cross-Site Scripting. It's abbreviated as XSS (not CSS) to avoid confusion with Cascading Style Sheets.

questions.question: What is the main goal of an XSS attack?
options: To inject and execute malicious JavaScript in victim's browser
questions.explanation: XSS attacks inject malicious scripts (usually JavaScript) that execute in the victim's browser, allowing attackers to steal data, hijack sessions, or perform actions on behalf of users.

questions.question: Which of these can be stolen through XSS?
options: Session cookies, passwords, personal data entered by users
questions.explanation: XSS can steal session cookies (leading to account hijacking), capture passwords and sensitive data entered by users, and access any information available in the browser.

questions.question: What is Stored XSS (Persistent XSS)?
options: XSS that exists only in browser cache
Malicious script permanently stored on server and executed every time users view the content
questions.explanation: Stored XSS occurs when malicious script is saved on the server (e.g., in comments, profiles) and executes for every user who views that content. It's the most dangerous type because it affects many users automatically.

questions.question: What is the difference between Reflected XSS and Stored XSS?
options: Reflected XSS is in the URL and executes immediately; Stored XSS is saved on server and affects multiple users
Stored XSS only works on mobile devices
questions.explanation: Reflected XSS is delivered through a malicious link (URL parameter) and affects only the victim who clicks it. Stored XSS is saved in the database and automatically affects all users who view the infected content.

questions.question: What is the most effective way to prevent XSS?
options: Output encoding/escaping - converting dangerous characters like < > into safe forms
questions.explanation: Output encoding converts dangerous characters (< > " ' &) into safe HTML entities (< > etc.), preventing browser from interpreting user input as executable code. This is the primary defense against XSS.

questions.question: What is Content-Security-Policy (CSP)?
options: An HTTP header that tells browser which sources of scripts and content are trusted
questions.explanation: CSP is an HTTP header that controls where scripts, styles, and other resources can be loaded from. It can block inline scripts and allow only whitelisted sources, providing strong XSS protection.

questions.question: Why should session cookies have the HTTPOnly flag?
options: To make cookies work over HTTP only
To prevent JavaScript from accessing cookies, protecting against XSS cookie theft
questions.explanation: The HTTPOnly flag prevents JavaScript (including XSS attacks) from reading cookie values via document.cookie. This protects session cookies from being stolen even if XSS vulnerability exists.

questions.question: Which React method is dangerous and can lead to XSS if misused?
questions.explanation: dangerouslySetInnerHTML bypasses React's automatic escaping and inserts raw HTML. If used with unsanitized user input, it creates XSS vulnerability. Use it only with trusted, sanitized content.

questions.question: What is DOM-Based XSS?
options: XSS that attacks the Document Object Model
XSS where vulnerability is in client-side JavaScript that improperly processes user input without server involvement
XSS that only works in Chrome
questions.explanation: DOM-Based XSS occurs when client-side JavaScript reads user input (from URL, DOM) and inserts it into the page without sanitization. The malicious payload never reaches the server - it's processed entirely in the browser.
